title: Introduction
text:
Highlight Code
See lines 6-8.
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(subplot_kw={'projection': 'polar'})
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()

title: Module 01: Introduction
text:
Module Topics

Personal Introductions + Learning Goals

Teaching Modelling and Quantitative Data Analysis: What‚Äôs Wrong with the Status Quo?

The Status Quo
Statistical Golems
Null Hypothesis Significance Testing (NHST)
Bad Controls
Transparency and Accountability, Reproducibility, Ethics

We Can Do Better!

Statistical Problem Solving; Probabilistic, Systems, and Futures Thinking
Prior Knowledge; Causal Models and Good Controls
Reproducible Research and Model-based Data Analysis

Overview of Course Topics, Learning Objectives, Assessment Methods, and Software

title: Data, Methods, and Models for Future Cities
text: You can learn a bit more about me and my approach to teaching modelling and quantiative data analysis here.

title: Data, Methods, and Models for Future Cities
section: The Master of Future Cities (MFC) Program
text:
The Master of Future Cities (MFC) Program






The Future is Unknown



‚ÄúThe traditional approaches to studying, planning, managing, and visioning our cities are arguably struggling to address our challenges today and lack the capacity to critically explore and develop alternatives for a future city. There is need to move beyond the silos within cities and disciplinary boundaries to foster multidisciplinary and transdisciplinary thinking applied to urban challenges and futures.‚Äù
Learn more about the program here.





(Image from Michael Betancourt.)

text:
Preface

What to expect

How to give feedback

title: Additional Resources

title: Web-based and Social Media Research Methods
text:
Instructor Information



Dr.¬†John McLevey (he/him)
Knowledge Integration, Sociology & Legal Studies
University of Waterloo
Email: john.mclevey@uwaterloo.ca
Office Hours: Mondays, 1:00 - 4:00 pm or by appointment
Office: EV1-215, University of Waterloo

title: Web-based and Social Media Research Methods
text:
Course Description
This course is an introduction to social media and web-based research methods for social scientists. It has two overarching goals: (1) to introduce students to cutting-edge social and political research, with an emphasis on social influence, disinformation and manipulation, political opinions, and the use of social media and other communications technologies by states and social movements; and (2) to help students develop a foundational skillset in collecting, processing, and analysing social media and web-based data.

title: Web-based and Social Media Research Methods
text:
Required Books
We will read the following 4 books over the course of the semester. See the Course Schedule for details on weekly reading assignments.

Zeynep Tufekci (2017), Twitter and Tear Gas: The Power and Fragility of Networked Protest
Molly Roberts (2018), Censored: Distraction and Diversion Insider China‚Äôs Great Firewall
Chris Bail (2022), Breaking the Social Media Prism: How to Make Our Platforms Less Polarizing
Philip Howard (2020), Lie Machines: How to Save Democracy from Troll Armies, Deceitful Robots, Junk News Operations, and Political Operatives

title: Web-based and Social Media Research Methods
text:
Research Software
This course will use the programming language Python to collect, process, and analyze social media data. While some previous experience with programming is beneficial, it is not required or assumed. You will have access to all code I present in lab sessions, and you will not be expected to write your own code (although you are welcome to do so).1

title: Web-based and Social Media Research Methods
text:
Assessment

Midterm and Final Exam
2 Posts on the Course Blog

1 conceptual / reading response
1 data analysis

title: Web-based and Social Media Research Methods
text:
Course Schedule
All content linked below can also be accessed from the menu at the top of the course website.




Topic
Assigned Reading




Module 01 (LEC)
Introduction to the Course; Ethics, Politics, and Privacy



Module 01 (LAB)

Echo Chambers, Filter Bubbles, and Polarization

Module 04 (LAB)

Roberts pages 1-92


Module 05 (LAB)
Echo Chambers in Interaction and Discussion Networks (II)



Module 06 (LEC)
Social Media and State Censorship
Roberts pages 93-187


Module 06 (LAB)
Text Analysis - Qualitative and Quantitative Methods



Module 07 (LEC)
Social Media and State Censorship
Roberts pages 190-240


Module 07 (LAB)

Tufecki pages 1-114

Module 12 (LEC)
Media, Social Media, Democracy, and Dictatorship
Howard pages 82-170

Political Ideologies and Belief Networks (II)
